    SPATA & Other Platforms

    spata-v2-platform-compatibility.Rmd

    1. Introduction

    Apart from SPATA2 there have been published several packages that devote themself to the analysis of sequencing data. Two of them are monocle3 and seurat. This article demonstrates how to leverage SPATA2’s compatibility.

    2. Monocle3

    The package monocle3 provides a variety of tools to analyze and visualize single-cell-sequencing data. Though spatial transcriptomic experiments do not reach the resolution of single-cell-sequencing yet you can leverage a variety of monocle3’s functions for your analysis and easily integrate the results back to your spata-object.

    # load packages
library(SPATA2)
library(magrittr)

library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork)

library(monocle3)

# load example of human brain cortex
spata_obj <- loadSpataObject("data/spata-obj-cortex265.RDS") # new

    In order to work with the functions of monocle3 you need to compile it’s core object: the cell_data-set. You can do that with ease with transformSpataToCDS(). It is a wrapper around all of monocle3’s pre processing functions, takes your spata-object of interest and creates a cell_data_set from it’s count matrix. Convenient argument input via named lists and defensive error handling via base::tryCatch() allow more experienced users to tweak the pre processing results. For the sake of simplicity we stick to the default options throughout this example.

    # compile a cell-data-set
cortex_cds <- transformSpataToCDS(object = spata_obj)

    To keep track of corresponding objects of different platforms you can store the directories under which you save them in the spata-object. To obtain the directories that are currently stored use getDirectoryInstructions(). Add the directory to the corresponding cell_data_set via adjustDirectoryInstruction().

    spata_obj <- adjustDirectoryInstructions(object = spata_obj,
                                            to = "cell_data_set",
                                            directory_new = "data/cds-cortex265.RDS")
    # obtain the directories that are currently stored in the spata-object
getDirectoryInstructions(object = spata_obj)
    ## $cell_data_set
## [1] "data/cds-cortex265.RDS"
## 
## $seurat_object
## [1] "data/seurat-obj-cortex265.RDS"
## 
## $spata_object
## [1] "data/spata-obj-cortex265.RDS"

    To save or load a corresponding cell_data_set under the default directory stored in the spata-object use saveCorrespondingCDS() and loadCorrespondingCDS()

    # use the directory information of the spata-object to conveniently save the cell_data_set
saveCorrespondingCDS(cds = cds, object = spata_obj)
    # use the directory information of the spata-object to conveniently load the cell_data_set
cortex_cds <- loadCorrespondingCDS(object = spata_obj) 
    spata_plot <- 
  plotSurface(spata_obj, color_by = "seurat_clusters", pt_clrp = "npg", pt_size = 1.4) + 
      legendBottom()


# SPATAS transform functions pass the feature data to the compiled object which makes 
# all features computed by yourself available, e.g. for monocle3::plot_cells()
monocle_plot <- 
  plot_cells(cortex_cds,
             reduction_method = "UMAP",
             color_cells_by = "seurat_clusters" # visualize a transferred variable
             ) +
      scale_color_add_on(aes = "color", variable = "discrete", clrp = "npg") +
      legendNone() 

# output 1 & 2 
spata_plot

monocle_plot

    Figure 2.1 SPATA’s and monocle3’ basic plotting results

    Example: Pseudotime

    If you haven’t done it already during cortex_cds’s compilation you can use moncle3::order_cells() to work with pseudotime - a measurement of how much progress cells have made through a process such as cell differentiation.

    # the pseudotime values for all cells/barcode-spots are obtained via
pseudotime_vec <- monocle3::pseudotime(cortex_cds)

# subset output
pseudotime_vec[1:10]
    ## AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1 AAACACCAATAACTGC-1 AAACAGTGTTCCTGGG-1 AAACATTTCCCGGATT-1 
##        17.99675712         0.05947085         0.05946980        13.00497429 
## AAACCCGAACGAAATC-1 AAACCGGAAATGTTAA-1 AAACCGGGTAGGTACC-1 AAACCGTTCGTCCAGG-1 
##        19.24685707        18.82008481         1.21056350         0.05946874 
## AAACCTAAGCAGCCGG-1 AAACCTCATGAAGTTG-1 
##         9.59278155         8.54330799

    The output of monocle3::pseudotime() is a named vector of numeric values. The numeric value refers to a barcode-spot’s pseudotime value and the name to it’s barcode. We can easily join this information to our original spata-object with a little bit of data wrangling and the addFeatures()-function.

    # 1. convert to data.frame 
pseudotime_df <- 
  base::as.data.frame(pseudotime_vec)

# output
head(pseudotime_df)
    ##                    pseudotime_vec
## AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1    17.99675712
## AAACACCAATAACTGC-1     0.05947085
## AAACAGTGTTCCTGGG-1     0.05946980
## AAACATTTCCCGGATT-1    13.00497429
## AAACCCGAACGAAATC-1    19.24685707
## AAACCGGAAATGTTAA-1    18.82008481
    # 2. create a barcodes-key variable and rename the pseudotime variable 
feature_df <- 
  magrittr::set_colnames(x = pseudotime_df, value = "Pseudotime") %>% 
  tibble::rownames_to_column(var = "barcodes")

# output
head(feature_df)
    ##             barcodes  Pseudotime
## 1 AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1 17.99675712
## 2 AAACACCAATAACTGC-1  0.05947085
## 3 AAACAGTGTTCCTGGG-1  0.05946980
## 4 AAACATTTCCCGGATT-1 13.00497429
## 5 AAACCCGAACGAAATC-1 19.24685707
## 6 AAACCGGAAATGTTAA-1 18.82008481
    # 3. add to spata-object via 
spata_obj <- addFeatures(object = spata_obj,
                         feature_names = "Pseudotime", 
                         feature_df = feature_df, 
                         overwrite = TRUE)

    The feature Pseudotime is now a valid feature in our spata-object and thus accessible via all functions in SPATA2 that take numeric features as an input option.

    # visualize pseudotime on the surface
plotSurface(spata_obj, color_by = "Pseudotime", smooth = TRUE, smooth_span = 0.2, pt_size = 1.8)

    Figure 3.2 Visualizing monocle3-pseudotime results with SPATA

    3. Seurat

    seurat provides a variety of computational tools. Initiating a SPATA2-object currently relies on most of it’s pre processing functions. If you want to switch from SPATA2 to Seurat make use of transformSpataToSeurat(). Similarly to initiateSpataObject_10X() and initiateSpataObject_CountMtr() it is a wrapper around several preprocessing functions although it passes the feature-data of your spata-object to it in order not to loose your progress. It works in a similar fashion as transformSpataToCDS().

    cortex_seurat <- transformSpataToSeurat(object = spata_obj)

    You can now continue your analysis with Seurat. Note that SPATA2 handles the image plotting differently which results in mirror-inverted plots.

    # continue analysis adn plotting with seurat
Seurat::SpatialFeaturePlot(object = cortex_seurat, features = "Pseudotime")

    Figure 4.1 Continue plotting and analysis with Seurat

    Note that the meta.data slot of the seurat-object contains the barcodes- and the sample-variable of the spata-object it originally derived from.

    # output
head(cortex_seurat@meta.data)
    ##                       orig.ident nCount_Spatial nFeature_Spatial sample
## AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1 SeuratProject           1809             1287   C265
## AAACACCAATAACTGC-1 SeuratProject           1772             1235   C265
## AAACAGTGTTCCTGGG-1 SeuratProject           1445             1057   C265
## AAACATTTCCCGGATT-1 SeuratProject           2198             1476   C265
## AAACCCGAACGAAATC-1 SeuratProject           2814             1811   C265
## AAACCGGAAATGTTAA-1 SeuratProject           2900             1880   C265
##                    percent.mt percent.RB Spatial_snn_res.0.8 seurat_clusters
## AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1   1.492537          0                   2               2
## AAACACCAATAACTGC-1   1.523702          0                   5               5
## AAACAGTGTTCCTGGG-1   1.453287          0                   4               4
## AAACATTTCCCGGATT-1   1.865332          0                   2               2
## AAACCCGAACGAAATC-1   1.279318          0                   0               0
## AAACCGGAAATGTTAA-1   1.586207          0                   0               0
##                    segmentation  Pseudotime mncl_cluster_umap
## AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1         none 17.99675712                 1
## AAACACCAATAACTGC-1         none  0.05947085                 1
## AAACAGTGTTCCTGGG-1         none  0.05946980                 1
## AAACATTTCCCGGATT-1         none 13.00497429                 1
## AAACCCGAACGAAATC-1         none 19.24685707                 1
## AAACCGGAAATGTTAA-1         none 18.82008481                 1
